To find the values of \( $$x$$ \) such that \( \left|  rac{-6}{3-x} ight| $$=$$ $$6$$ \), we can consider two cases for the absolute value expression:

Case 1:
\[
 rac{-6}{3-x} $$=$$ $$6$$
\]
Multiplying both sides by \( $$3-x$$ \), we have:
\[
$$-6$$ $$=$$ $$6(3-x)$$
\]
\[
$$-6$$ $$=$$ $$18$$ - $$6x$$
\]
Adding \( $$6x$$ \) to both sides:
\[
$$6x$$ - $$6$$ $$=$$ $$18$$
\]
Adding $$6$$ to both sides:
\[
$$6x$$ $$=$$ $$12$$
\]
Dividing both sides by 6:
\[
$$x$$ $$=$$ $$2$$
\]

Case 2:
\[
 rac{-6}{3-x} $$=$$ $$-6$$
\]
Multiplying both sides by \( $$3-x$$ \), we have:
\[
$$-6$$ $$=$$ $$-6(3-x)$$
\]
\[
$$-6$$ $$=$$ $$-18$$ + $$6x$$
\]
Adding $$18$$ to both sides:
\[
$$12$$ $$=$$ $$6x$$
\]
Dividing both sides by 6:
\[
$$x$$ $$=$$ $$2$$
\]

In both cases, we find that the solution is \( $$x$$ $$=$$ $$2$$ \).

However, we must ensure that this doesn't cause division by zero, i.e., \( $$3-x$$ 
eq $$0$$ \). In this case, \( $$3-x$$ $$=$$ $$1$$ 
eq $$0$$ \) when \( $$x$$ $$=$$ $$2$$ \), so it is valid. Therefore, the only value of \( $$x$$ \) that satisfies the equation is $$2$$. Thus, the correct choices should indicate only \( $$2$$ \).
